comments.commentBody: I like what the researchers are trying to do.  But, I wish they would broaden their research to include using these games to reproduce the beneficial "brain states" produced by meditation, positive imagery, and optimistic attitudes.   Even the feeling of being loved has a beneficial effect on healing.   Wouldn't it be great if computers could help us boost our immune system or speed up bone healing?  There are possibilities here and I hope the researchers realize these possibilities.  Please don't just rely on neuro imaging to measure responses and measure success.  There are other ways to measure physical responses to these games and they might give a hint on the possibilities for the future.  Wouldn't it be cool to be able to "play" a game to stimulate certain internal chemical and neuronal responses and cure your respiratory infection?  Might we be looking at the research that will someday lead to a cure for the common cold?  I wanted to research this topic when I was a graduate student at UW Madison back in the 80s, but couldn't find a major professor who would take me (and my wild ideas) on.  Maybe computers will be the key that will help us change how we think about illness and healing.  Thank you for the article and my thanks to the researchers.  You are giving us hope for the future.

Feynman:

"What science is, I think, may be something like this...is it possible to learn more rapidly what somebody learned from some accident than the rate at which the thing is being forgotten...?

So there came a time, perhaps, when for some species [humans?] the rate at which learning was increased [that] things could be learned by one individual animal, passed on to another, and another, fast enough that it was not lost to the race. Thus became possible an accumulation of knowledge of the race.

This phenomenon of having a memory for the race, of having an accumulated knowledge...had a disease in it: it was possible to pass on ideas which were not profitable for the race. The race has ideas, but they are not necessarily profitable.

So there came a time in which the ideas, although accumulated very slowly, were all accumulations not only of practical and useful things, but great accumulations of all types of prejudices, and strange and odd beliefs.

Then a way of avoiding the disease was discovered. This is to doubt that what is being passed from the past is in fact true, and to try to find out ab initio again from experience what the situation is, rather than trusting the experience of the past in the form in which it is passed down. And that is what science is: the result of the discovery that it is worthwhile rechecking by new direct experience, and not necessarily trusting the [human] race['s] experience from the past."
I'm giving you a recco.

A B-boy is what northern Canadians (and most other white people) call a "breakdancer."  That term comes from the hip-hop slang "beatbreak" for a rap song's bridge which is nothing but percussion, and was the favorite soundtrack for this kind of street performance.  Breakdancers universally hate that term, and usually call themselves "B-boys."  The line of headphones "Beats by Dr. Dre" is named for the same beatbreak.

A fine helpful article on your part, Ms. Wampole, with a guiding light and reminder for many of us in a myriad of ways, and in conformity with our respective natures. As I grow more mature, I know today topics to avoid that I find unsettling, what direction to choose when it comes to placing my focus in areas all to the good and my liking, where I may be able to be at my best, in order to help others as well in turn, and at their request.

At times in life, one can find oneself in complex, sensitive, or crippling situations, and I find that by stepping out of myself and looking in a detached way at the circumstances and the people in such a scenario, it helps to be more objective in evaluating the big picture. Rather than becoming confrontational if an unkind or unjust act has taken place, I do not let on, or even pretend to know, but rise above the situation and soar high.

It takes ongoing practice and accrued life experience, but I do believe that inner-turmoil is most damaging, and the best way to cope is to carry on, coupled with some humor at the absurdity of it all. Taking one self's too seriously can be a serious pitfall.

In summary, when prompted to react in anger, I find that laughing inwardly at the provoking party or situation, wearing a cloak of invisibility, maintaining one's composure and remaining calm, have helped achieve a sense of inner peace. It takes time to achieve this, perhaps a lifetime, but it is well worth it, and as good as it gets.

I too am very concerned about upward mobility. Equal opportunity has always been the essence of the United States. But I would take exception to the use of quintiles as a method of measuring results. Yes, someone born in the bottom quintile has only an 8 or 9 percent chance to make the top quintile, but using that measure means they are displacing someone from the top quintile. Or put another way, for every person who rises up from the bottom quintile, someone else has to fall down into the bottom quintile. I think that any measure of upward mobility that requires an equal amount of downward mobility is not a valid concept. It is a false indicator and looks at mobility in a way I think we should be loathe to promote.

Romanians loved their VCRs.  When visiting Romania in January 1990 immediately following the December Revolution that ousted and killed Nicolae Ceaușescu and his wife, Elena, every single household I visited insisted that I view their very own personal VHS copy of his fatal speech following the Timișoara riots.  I could never refuse sharing their newly won joy and first taste of freedom after decades of grinding totalitarianism.

One of my professor's lived in Romania during the Communist regime. People kept asking him for books from America. He would give a book to a Romanian who would type the entire book by hand. Then that person would pass the book to another, who would type the book and pass it on. Each person who read the books would type them out and pass the copies around. The Romanians were so desperate for books that they were willing to type hundreds of pages of each book.
The professor said this after coming back to America. "In Romania, where they have no books, everybody reads. In America, where you can have any book you want, nobody reads."
If books were banned here, would they become precious to us?

In fact, "Stand Your Ground" is embedded in the Florida statute dealing with the "use of deadly force" in self-defense, and was specifically cited by Dunn's lawyer and noted in the judge's instructions to the jury. During closing arguments, Dunn's lawyer Cory Strolla explained, "His honor will further tell you that if Michael Dunn was not engaged in an unlawful activity and was attacked in a public place where he had a legal right to be, a public parking lot asking for a common courtesy, saying thank you, trying to tell the guy I said thank you. He had no duty to retreat and had the right to stand his ground and meet force with force, including deadly force." Strolla later added of the law, "It's not because I wrote it. It's not cause I like it. We're not here to change it and we're not here to fight it. We're here to apply it."
